How do you do? Varric Tethras, at your service!
So, here's the thing: we need to find a way into the Deep Roads.
Bartrand can lead us to the right place once we're down there, but we need a good entrance.
How do you plan an expedition into the Deep Roads without knowing a way in?
Isn't that kind of important?
I've fought darkspawn, but I've never been to the Deep Roads.
How do we do that?
Any entrance would do, wouldn't it? Unless a dragon's sitting in it, I suppose.
Do we have a bad entrance?
We need an entrance that's close to our destination but isn't already plundered or filled with darkspawn.
Fortunately, I've received some new information.
There's a Grey Warden in the city. If anyone knows how to get down there, it'll be him.
Why would a Grey Warden know that?
How can you be so sure?
The Wardens don't just fight darkspawn; they forge into the Deep Roads all the time.
And if he doesn't know, he might be able to point us to those who do.
Are there any other options?
And if he knows nothing?
None at the moment. Bartrand had an entrance lined up, but it was a bust.
I'll keep looking, but if we don't find something, we'll have a fancy expedition with nowhere to go.
We may need to wring it out of him. Wardens can be secretive.
If we can make him talk.
We don't want trouble with the Grey Wardens, do we?
Wardens are dangerous.
Let's look at our options, first. I'd rather not fight a Warden unless we have to.
Sounds like you have it all planned out, Varric.
Problem solved!
And that, messere, is why I'm here.
Supposedly, this Grey Warden came in with some other Fereldan refugees not long ago.
A Lowtown woman named Lirene has been helping the Fereldans. We talk to her, maybe we learn where he is.
Now, onto other matters: I think I have something that might interest you.
I have a guy that can get us some work with the thieves' guild.
How much do you know about them?
The thieves' guild?
I'm not a member, if that's what you're asking. But I know some of their people.
The Coterie is the strongest guild in Kirkwall. If you care to bed anyone, they'd be the ones to court.
Point me to him. I need all the work I can get.
Sounds good.
This just reeks of trouble.
I don't know...
And coin. They go hand in hand, you know.
Gallard's in Darktown. Probably worth knowing what he has in mind, even if you're not interested.
I'll keep after my contacts—see if I can drum up any other work.
I apologize for Bartrand. He wouldn't know an opportunity if it hit him square in the jaw.
But you would?
I would! What my brother doesn't realize is that we need someone like you.
He would never admit it, either—he's too proud. I, however, am quite practical.
You're part of Bartrand's venture?
Are you in the expedition?
That's right! The Deep Roads wouldn't normally be my thing, but I can't allow the head of our family to go down there alone.
So as you might imagine, I have more than a passing interest in this expedition's success.
What makes you so certain we can help? You know nothing about us.
You know who we are?
On the contrary—you've made quite the name for yourself over the last year.
Serving with the Red Iron is no mean feat; yet you not only served, you impressed!
The Coterie has been squeezing smugglers out left and right, and the only group to survive owes it all to you two.
The name Hawke is on many lips these days. Not bad for a Fereldan fresh off the boat!
He said he didn't need another guard.
Your brother refused me.
There must be some way to persuade your brother to hire us on.
How do we reason with him?
You're going awfully far out of your way just to hire another guard.
You're a little too smooth.
We don't need another hireling—we need a partner!
The truth is, Bartrand's been tearing his beard out trying to fund this on his own, but he can't do it.
Invest in the expedition. A hundred sovereigns, and he can't refuse. Not with me there to vouch for you.
Your brother doesn't seem like the sort who's willing to split profits.
He'll share the profits?
My brother is many things, but he's not stupid.
Far better to share the profits than be trapped in a thaig with a thousand darkspawn between you and the exit.

No! Please!
She should consider reinstating Samson. When it came down to it, he showed where his heart is.
Give Samson another chance.
True. Samson, you have done us a great service. Do you wish to take up the shield once more?
M-more than anything, Knight-Captain ser!
Then I'll see what I can do.
Thank you, ser!

Perhaps we can still hold on to peace.

I would have had him executed immediately, but the boy's father made an impassioned appeal on his behalf.
What say you, Champion? Do you believe Emile to be dangerous?
He was never a danger to anyone but himself.
No.
He told people he was a blood mage to get girls. Lock him up and you'll be fine.
He's an idiot.
Stupidity can be dangerous, and he has that in spades.

Chuckles

Very well, Emile will keep his life, though I will watch him closely.

Speak to Elsa. She can provide you with compensation for the time you spent on this task.
I'm pleased to have played a part in keeping the city safe.
Glad I could help.
Wait. That's it? Pay us and send us on our way?
Not a single thought given to the fact that you templars brought all of this upon yourselves?
Be very careful, mage. Your friendship with the Champion protects you only so much.
This is not the time, Anders.
Anders, be quiet.
You've gone too far, and you know it.
Anders is right.
Maybe if you never took Huon from his wife, she wouldn't be dead!

I bid you good day, Champion.

Anders, be quiet.

Maybe Anders is right.

Enough. I have not the patience to argue with you further.
Emile was killed.
He's dead.
I let him go. He's no harm to anyone.
He's gone.

Sighs Perhaps some of them might still be saved.
We'll protect your precious shipment. Just make sure you have the Coterie's payment.
They're not letting anyone into the city.
What? That can't be!
It's true. Look at them all.
They're Fereldans, just like us. Fleeing for their lives.
Are we really surprised? Everyone's fleeing the Blight, just as we are.
And they would throw us all back to the wolves. Unbelievable.
We're getting into the city, one way or another.
They can try.
So long as we're all safe, that's more important.
Is everyone all right?
I'm only surprised they let us dock.
It's totally believable.
We need to find Gamlen. Our family has always been highly regarded in Kirkwall. He can do something, I'm sure of it!
Let's hope he received your letter.
Let's hope he received your letter.
The guards seem to be reporting to that man. Perhaps we should speak to him.
I've heard you have dealings with certain... elements... in the city. You can get things done, on the sly as they say?
Well, dog. Are you ready to bark now?
Sabin will pay you back if you let him go.
Sabin will make this right.
They even killed his dog to prove a point. His dog, Hubert! You know how important they are to Fereldans.
So that was your uncle, was it? Good. I thought he was another confidence man trying to sell promises.
I don't suppose he has the coin you'll need to get in.
He doesn't seem to have any more than we do.
No, he doesn't.
Ah, that's a shame.
We just helped save your life. Isn't that worth something?
What about our help?
He had some ideas.
He might have a way.
They always do.
If it were just up to me, I'd let you through. But there are a lot of eyes watching, a lot of palms that need greasing.
My suggestion? Wait for a ship and hope the next city hasn't already closed their doors.
Good luck, whatever you do.
You've gained quite a reputation with the Red Iron mercenary band.
I find myself in need of someone with your… special talents.
What of it, old man?
And?
I am a magistrate in this city and I expect to be addressed with respect. Especially from someone who might be working for me soon...
Is there something I can help with?
What is it you need?
I am a magistrate in this city and as such, I wish to hire you for a small, albeit important, job.
That's a fancy way to put it.
On the sly?
This does not make it right, what he did. But it takes the sting off. After all I have done for these poor refugees...
All you've done?
Feh. There's a thousand such sob stories in Lowtown.
There's an ambush planned tonight at Dietrich Crossing.
Oh really? I am more inclined to beat the coin out of this sheep swallop. And then kill him.
He's nothing, Hubert. Take his offer and cut him loose so we can get back to business.
Fine! Get me your ill-gotten coin before I change my mind.
A public showing of mercy will be good for morale. Let him go.
We're letting Sabin go.
Get back to the crowd, you lot. Trying to bully your way through won't get you into Kirkwall any faster!
But you do intend to let us in?
There must be someone in charge I can speak with.
Tell me who to talk to.
Sighs Yes, yes, always the same story.
Talk to Captain Ewald. Don't talk to me.
I guess saving his ass didn't get you into the city either, huh? Laughs
I wouldn't laugh quite so loudly if I were you.
Yes, well. Yes.

A Letter from Emile de Launcet
As must we. Come, Alain. I'm sorry you were the only one I could save.

Dear Hawke,
Thank you for your trust and giving me the chance to truly live. You don't have to worry about me. The Circle, as strict as it was, taught me well. As long as I keep my mouth shut and stay away from magic, I should be all right.
I've since bedded a woman much better looking than any wench in the Hanged Man. I wrote another letter with all the details, but you probably don't want to hear about it. (I've learned some discretion! Aren't you proud of me?)
Anyway, I've enclosed a little item that helped my studies in the Circle. I no longer need it, and maybe you'll meet someone who can put it to good use.
Ever grateful, Emile de Launcet

A Messy Handwritten Note
I'm sorry it turned out this way.

Messere Hawke,
Thank you so much for telling Bodahn about us. He knows many people in Kirkwall and has found homes and jobs for most of us. I'm helping him out as a delivery boy. Much better than digging in the trash for food!
Cricket now lives with a nice family in Hightown. They saw him at the marketplace and wanted to help. They even tried giving him a new name! Charles, maybe, but he answers only to Cricket.
Thanks again for helping us. I'll never forget you.
Your friend, Walter
Varric? I can't... hear the song anymore...
I'll make your blood and bones sing the song for me!
Do it or don't, but get out of my sight, Fereldan.
She pities these things. I don't share her concern.
With any luck, he'll make a good example.
My life's not worth much, but my family... I only wanted to give my wife and son a better life.
Ah! Welcome, my dear friend, to Sol's shop. My name is Solivitus. Please, take a look around.
My apologies in advance. Our shelves are a bit bare at the moment.
Actually, if you're interested, I could use a bit of help to remedy that.
How can I help?
What do you need?
Talk.
Get on with it.
All business. I like you.
Remedy that. Potions shop. You, my good man, are priceless.
Remedy that?
The pun wasn't intentional, although I may use that next time!
It's been too dangerous to leave the city of late, and the substances I require for my creations are, of course, elsewhere.
Perhaps you could find them. You'll be compensated for your time, have no fear. I'll also give you first pick of my new creations!
Make up a list of what you need, and I'll keep an eye out for you.
I'm in.
Perfect! A discount on everything in the shop, serah!
Sorry, I'm not interested.
No thanks.
Ah. Well, that's unfortunate.
The spider's silk gland! I hope the fellow you took this from didn't give you much trouble.
The dragon's fang! It's larger than I expected.
Pure ironwood! It's perfect!
Welcome back to Sol's, my friend!
You're looking well! My store is much better stocked, thanks to you!
If you're interested in hunting down more ingredients, I can make other creations. And of course, I'll pay you for your work!
Sure, just let me know what you need.
I'll do it.
Perfect! I have a list of the ingredients right here.
I appreciate the offer, but I have to decline.
No thanks.
That's disappointing, but I'm grateful for everything you've done. You'll always have a discount at my shop!
This is a waste of my time.
No thanks.
Oh. Well... Do know you're always welcome at my shop.
I'm afraid my skills are needed elsewhere.
No thanks.
Of course, of course. Come back anytime. The discount still stands!
Harlot's Blush! What a scandalous name for such a pretty flower...
The Dalish actually agreed to part with the ink? Or did you... No, never mind. Better that I don't know.
Ew. Perhaps allow more of the blood to drain from the heart next time?
Welcome back to Sol's, my friend!
A man I sentenced to a life in prison has escaped custody. He's been tracked to an abandoned ruin outside the city.
I'd like you to retrieve the fugitive, and hand him over to the guard.
We're both intelligent people. There's something in the ruins, isn't there?
This sounds too easy.
Why is there such a clamor to catch this man, what has he done?
What was this man's crime?
The guards can take care of this, unless there's something else you're not telling me.
This is a grunt job.
The men refuse to go in without reinforcements. The ruins have been overrun by strange... creatures.
I'm sure if you send in enough men this time, they'd do fine.
So why not send more guards?
No. The more guards who know, the easier it is for this to get out. Those men gossip like old fishwives.
It would be easier to seal up the entrance and let the beasts take care of him.
Why not just let him be eaten?
I believe in justice, Fereldan, not unbridled slaughter.
I'll take the job.
All right, I'll do it.
Bring the fugitive in alive, quickly and quietly.
You'll have to find someone else, Magistrate. I don't have the time right now.
No, I can't help you.
That is very disappointing. I want to keep this quiet. To do that, I can't send a whole squadron to apprehend one man.
If you change your mind—and I hope you do—I'll be here.
I'll deal with Hubert. Just give us something to go on.
I'll help you.
Oh thank you, messere! I'll talk.
So you value your family's welfare over the lives of others?
You're beyond redemption.
I'll make sure your family is taken care of.
I'll sweeten the pot.
I'm humbled by that offer. Thank you.
Welcome back, my friend! My store has never been better stocked, thanks to you!
Although I have nothing else to ask you to find, you're quite welcome to bring back any rare specimens you may come across.
I took this fire gland from a high dragon just outside the city.
You killed a high dragon? Incredible! Let me see the fire gland...
Just hurry up. You're wasting my time.
Take it.
This fire gland is a remarkable specimen... Wait here. I know exactly what I can craft from this.
This turned out beautifully! Something worthy of our Champion. I hope you can put it to good use.
So good to see you, Champion!

Could you pay Hubert back?

Gamlen!

I don't like this idea.

I don't like this idea.

I don't like this idea.

The catch is you and your sister have to work off the debt. For a year.
The catch is you and your brother will have to work off the debt. For a year.
A year!

Wonderful.

Find Bartrand and put a stop to his depravity.
Bartrand has been found alive and stark raving mad.
Varric got revenge on his brother for his betrayal in the Deep Roads.
That doesn't excuse murder!
Are these elves telling the truth?
Is it true, Aveline?
There have been rumors. I will investigate, but they still took the law into their own hands.
Your law has failed viddathari before. If I cannot be satisfied, why should the lowest of you expect different?
I don't know. But that doesn't make what they did right.
I would have done the same thing, in their shoes.
Yes it does.
Hawke, that's not helping.
What these men did was wrong.
Aveline is right.
Their actions are mere symptoms. Your society is the disease.
They have chosen. The viddathari will submit to the Qun and find a path your way has denied them.
You can't just decide that. You must hand them over.
Tell me, Hawke: what would you do, in my place?
Give us the elves or we'll take them by force.
Just hand them over!
Hawke...
Impressive. But I am committed.
This isn't Qunari land, and they aren't your people.
Let us arrest them.
I see.
As a guest in this city, I would keep the peace.
Let us arrest them.
They would make poor Qunari without the horns.
Let us arrest them.
I'd fight anyone who tried to take them from me.
I wouldn't give them up.
Exactly so.
They deserve another chance.
I wouldn't give them up.
Why pass up perfectly good converts?
I wouldn't give them up.
You clearly don't like staying amongst humans.
Why not leave the city?
I cannot leave without the relic, and I cannot stay and remain blind to this dysfunction.
There is only one solution.
I sent others before, but no word. Perhaps they are putting me off! I need someone competent to figure out what is going on.
I'll head there soon.
That's all I need to know.
Your first mistake was naming your mine the Bone Pit.
Is Bone Pit a tad ominous?
The locals named the mine. Those fools say it is cursed.
That is why I hire Fereldans. They may be dull-witted, but they are not superstitious.
Mind what you say about my countrymen.
You know I'm one of them?
I was not referring to you, of course. My workers are a particularly desperate sort.
They are lucky to work for me. Few in Kirkwall will hire refugees.
I am at a loss! No miner has reported in, and no one takes me seriously.
I will pay handsomely. The exact amount depends on what perils you face.
I solved your problem.
So, what happened? One of the miners told me you rescued him from dragons. I cuffed him for lying.
But... I thought they're extinct! Eh, I believe you. You made them extinct again? If it is safe, the miners can return to work.
I appreciate your concern for my worker's welfare. I could use someone like you to ensure their continued safety.
I bet their first task will be cleaning up the entrails the last shift left behind.
I don't envy them.
A dragon killer and a mind reader. Wonderful!
So to our first order of business: we replace the lost workers.

I know that respect is hard won, but it also earns privilege.
You have granted this woman basalit-an. By this admission, she now has the right to challenge you.

You betrayed me!
You caused this!

I thought you'd be long gone by now.
I'm glad you returned.
Heroic acts of sacrifice? What will people say?
This is unlike you.
This is your damned influence, Hawke.
I was halfway to Ostwick before I knew I had to turn around. It's pathetic.
The relic is reclaimed. I am now free to return to Par Vollen—with the thief.
What?
She stole the Tome of Koslun. She must return with us.
Sounds like you have something very specific in mind.
What exactly will you do?
She will submit to the Qun and the Ben-Hassrath. More than that I will not say.
Take her and go.
I agree.

You have your relic. She stays with us.
You can't have her.
Isabela will answer according to our laws, not yours.
We'll punish her.
It is done.
You knew the risks, Isabela. You always did.
You have to see it through.
This is what I get for believing you were different, that you... cared about me.
I should have known better than to come back. Won't make that mistake again.
I have no choice, Isabela.
There's always a choice! I made a choice!
I'm not going to fight you.
He's right, Isabela.
It figures. I always knew you didn't have it in you.
Then you leave me no choice.
I challenge you, Hawke. You and I will battle to the death, with her as the prize.
No! If you're going to duel anyone, duel me!
You are not basalit-an. You are unworthy.
Don't you have what you came for?
Why not take the relic and go?
You know we do not suffer thieves. She cannot walk away from this insult.
I will take her. If you object, duty demands that we fight.
If there's no other way, then do it.
Then take her.
I accept your challenge.
I will fight you.
I refuse your challenge.
I won't duel.
You're right. We are hardly the only ones to bear that grief.
A fair point.
Precisely.
Why don't you just stab me in the back while you're at it?
Ouch. Low blow!
Leave my mother out of this!
How dare you.
Cold corpses speak louder than abstract freedoms, do they not?
As long as that's true, Kirkwall needs its templars more than it needs a new ruler.
Those magickers need to be taught a lesson.
The knight-commander's getting out of control.
The knight-commander's right. We don't have time for politics until the mages are under control.

Those robes are always trying to change our minds. They shouldn't be allowed to speak in public.
I've got a daughter in the Circle. There's a lot of mages in the city who aren't blood mages.
We're not safe while mages walk the streets.
Would you be our viscount, Champion? I know I'd feel safe with you in the Keep.
That elf should hang for daring to speak against the knight-commander.
The knight-commander's mad. I wish you really were the viscount...
Wonderful! I was hoping you'd say yes!
Are you in need of any potions today, my friend?
Are you in need of any potions today, my friend?

Why the Keep?
They're going to take everyone of import and put them in the same place.
Those that agree to convert, live. Those that don't...
Charming.
To get everyone important in one place, where they can be controlled... or killed.

Whatever they are doing, we must stop them.
Ah, my young friend, you've returned!
I must sound like a Chanter, since I know you've heard me say this before but, are you perhaps interested in a small job?
I am still in need of a few rare ingredients that, I have to admit, are difficult to obtain.
Let me know what you need, and I'll see what I can do.
I'll do it.
I'm not interested.
No thanks.

I'm sorry to hear that.

Is there anything you can make from it?
Can you use it?

Hello, Sister. How fitting we should meet here.
Somehow, I knew it would be you.
Carver!

We're here on Grey Warden business.

Spread the word.

But you just got here.
You're leaving, Carver?
I've been here for six days.
Wait—I need to tell you about Mother.
Bethany, Mother's gone.
I know what happened. I waited and waited for you to tell me yourself. Did you hold a funeral, or was there not enough left?
Wait—I need to tell you about Mother.
Carver, Mother's gone.
I already know what happened. I'm sure you did your best.
Take this. It is all we can spare, but perhaps it will be of use.
Goodbye, Brother. Take care of yourself.
Goodbye, Sister. Take care of yourself.
Goodbye, big brother. Take care of yourself.
Goodbye, Sister. Take care of yourself.

I'm looking for ink.

That was helpful.

It's the statue.
Bloody ancestors! Why bring me this close and still nothing?

He doesn't want money?

He's too far gone.

Right. Still going to feel good pulling that trigger...
No! I've been counting the days until I could put a bolt in his conniving little brain.
It's not just us! Look what he did out there! How many more people will die for his folly?
He has to be stopped. There are other ways than murder.
He doesn't need to die.
Fine. We'll have to... lock him away somewhere. I'll send somebody to get him.
He's clearly past saving. Make it clean.
You're right.
I wish I could have done it before I had to see you like this. Goodbye, Bartrand.

Hold.

You are one of the few I have met with any ability. And yet this too was random, a result of selfishness.

You... like it?

I agree it's a mess.
Weakness provides opportunity.
But you don't see that as a problem?
I see it as an opportunity, and I intend to take full advantage.
Karasten are soldiers. The Qun made it so. They can never vary from that assigned path, never be other than they are meant to be.
But, they are free to choose within that role. To accept and succeed, or deny and die. Glory is clear and defined.
Could you—could not this entire city—benefit from that certainty? How else will you know when you have made a real difference?
You claim it is no different anywhere else. We deny that with a certainty that would benefit not just you, but this whole city.
You allow chaos for good or ill, but one is clearly superior. Can you see how that certainty would benefit this whole city?
It is an undeniable certainty. What full advantage can you take without that authority?
Sorry, I find myself distracted by deny and die.
Is that a threat?
And yet you accept the random violence that plagues this nation.
I wonder if the weaker of your citizens would be so closed to certainty?

He's free to choose to obey? That isn't contradictory to you?
Is it certainty or slavery?
He chooses to be. As do we all, long before any of your meaningless freedoms are presented.
I am not the one to educate you. I did not intend to land here.
But this city may demand certainty.
Have you come here to proselytize? To convert?
Did you come to convert us?

I suspect the day is coming soon. We are done, human.
I suspect we are done, human.
You guard your powder carefully.
Why not sell the gaatlok?

It could benefit many people.

Well, your children.
How many Qunari have you lost to the Tal-Vashoth?

None.
You can't believe that.
That seems unlikely.
Optimistic, considering my death toll.

I met an honorable one.
One of them warned me.
Doubtful.
He said he was a mercenary, not a murderer.

He is not even dead to the Qun—he is a living insult.
You're a long way from home. Why did you come?
What was your mission?

Or until the demand changes.
I don't think Kirkwall would do well under military rule.
You'd impose help on the city?

Saarebas chose death over leaving the Qun.
The mage refused freedom.
That is good to hear.
That is all you have to say?

I doubt Saarebas earned a greater honor in his life than my reaction now.

Shit, I really shouldn't have said that.

I'd hate to hear what you'd tell people if you didn't like me.

You're too kind.

Grand Cleric?

No price is too much when we speak of eternity!

Fools to the highest office.

I may come calling for your help one of these days.
Can I count on your support?

Lay low, for once.

Useless guards!

What do you sell?
Idunna, right?

Wilmod, Wilmod. That doesn't sound familiar.
I know he saw you frequently.

You're lying.

As charming and relentless as you are, I'm here to investigate.

Blood magic. It must be.
Maybe we can find answers somewhere around here. And then a cold shower.
Let's search her things. I bet she's got more secrets.
Search her room. We need to know what's going on.
She used blood magic against me. I didn't expect it to be so... powerful.
We should search for answers.
I've got the mother of all hangovers. I really hate blood mages.
We should search the room. Maybe we'll learn who she's working with.
She would have made a powerful magister. But the burial shroud suits her better.
We should look around.
Let's see what other secrets you've got...
I will not... be toyed with.
You can't control me.
How did you...? Oh, shit!
Spare me, messere!
What foul magic was that?
How did you do that?
You're going to answer all my questions. And if there's even a hint of magic...
Tell me everything. Now.
You're just too dangerous. You have to die.
No mercy for you.
We should just do what she says.

Sorry about that. I don't know what I was thinking.
I'm so sorry! I don't know what came over me.
I don't know. Be careful.
Blood and desire, in equal measure. An art I learned from... elsewhere.
They will be protected.
What are we waiting around for? Let's go break stuff in my brother's house until we unhaunt it!
Hey... is that music? Where is that coming from?
Gate Guard
I request an audience with the Arishok.
He will allow it, but not in this number.
I will only bring my friend here and a small complement of my guard. Is that few enough?
It is.
Enter.
The gates are closed by order of the Arishok.
Where's Aveline? I bet she could order them to open up.
One of the Dalish, a woman named Variel, is a friend of his. I suggest speaking with her first.
You wouldn't know it, but Bartrand was a sentimentalist. This came from our estate in Orzammar.
When I was seven, I knocked over one of Mother's plates and broke it. My brother yelled at me for an hour.
Your collusion in the Chantry has ensured I am hated whatever I do. How much pain will you allow to selfishly deny the Qun?
He's nothing but a murderer, a thief, and a liar.

I let your assassin go. Was I not supposed to do that?
Will everyone please just step back!
My mother's in labor! The baby's come early. Can anyone help her?
I'll send word to the healer, but—
My son's hurt bad. Cart overturned on him in the blasted Bone Pit.
Everyone in your turn. I promise, we have donations coming in. There will be food and medicine for all of you.
We serve everyone here—no one came from Ferelden without trouble.
But I can't give priority to anyone who's already found work and lodging.
Look at all this.
Magic is a cancer in the heart of our land, just as it was in the time of Andraste.
And like her we are left with no choice but to purify it with fire and blood.
You got what you wanted. It's done.
It's over.
You almost sound as if you're happy to do it.
You're enjoying this?
Strange way to treat a sick patient.
Death is an odd cure.

I'm a mage, remember?

I was afraid you were going to let everyone else do your fighting.
Finally.
Not at all.

You'll pay for what you've done here.
You're a monster.
I will be rewarded for what I've done here, in this world and the next!

I imagine you've wanted to be rid of me for some time.
Been waiting for this?
I bear you no ill will. You've done this to yourself.
You were never part of this Circle, and I tolerated that, but in defending them you've chosen to share their fate.
You are no mage, but in supporting them you've elected to share their fate.
Knight-Commander, I thought we intended to arrest the Champion.
You should have told him where he could shove that broken dish.
You let him push you around?

Blind Alley
What did you just do?
Yes, it was blood magic, but I know what I'm doing. The spirit helped us, didn't it?
Call it what it is. You summoned a demon.
The demon, you mean.

Merchants Guild ledgers. Sighs Dwarves fighting over whose ancestors were the dwarfiest, whose gold is the shiniest...

Yes, messere. Please don't kill me.
Tarohne put me here. To send biddable templar recruits to the sanctuary. Three Spear Alley, in the Undercity.
I enchanted Wilmod and Keran weeks ago. But after they left these walls, I know not what came of them.
If you've coin to spare, we won't turn it down. Donations go in the box up front.
Ah, so Zevran told you, did he? It really doesn't matter. This time his Warden isn't here to protect him.
Anything else?
Only Fereldan Grey Warden I've heard of is sitting on the throne.
Only Fereldan Grey Warden I've heard of died to save us all from the Archdemon. Fat lot they care here.
Only Fereldan Grey Warden I've heard of slew the Archdemon to save us all. Fat lot they care here.
We're out of the Blight's path now. Why would you need a Warden?

Well, he's not now. And busy enough without answering fool questions about it.
Who are you protecting?

I won't bother him.
Where is this healer?

He's a good man. I won't lose him to the blighted templars.
You mean he's a mage?
Lose him to the templars?
Would I stick my neck out for some purveyor of hensbane and leeches?

I mean him no harm.
Tell me he's got killer eyes and a nice smile, I'll marry him on the spot.
He sounds too good to be true.
No one's that selfless. He's probably got bodies hidden in his basement.
He sounds too good to be true.
I wouldn't worry so much about his safety. Worry about yours.
Tell me where he is. Or else.

The Arishok will see no one. He has begun preparations.

Yes it is.

Go without me. I need a stiff one and a drink.
You just go ahead. I have to pamper a kitty.

I think I left someone back at the Hanged Man.
Hey, I think I knew that man, back in Antiva! Bye!

Why would he give away his position?
He'll just give himself up?

He's doing nothing of the sort. He didn't want to endanger us, so he asked us not to get involved.

The conspiracy against you has been put down.

The conspirators are dead.

The first enchanter had no role in this.
Orsino is blameless.

Ooh, I'd love to be a fly on the wall when you and Orsino get together.
I'll let you two work it out.
Cullen tells me the first enchanter was not behind this, that one of our own led this scheme.
I do not believe it.
If you did not find proof, it means only that Orsino hid his tracks well. Who else was involved?
The templar Thrask, the templar Keran, the templar Samson. The mage Grace, the mage Alain. I do not know the others.
I'll name names.
The templar Thrask, the templar Keran, the templar Samson. The mage Grace. I do not know the others.
I'll name names.
The templar Thrask, the templar Keran. The mage Grace, the mage Alain. I do not know the others.
I'll name names.
The templar Thrask, the templar Keran. The mage Grace. I do not know the others.
I'll name names.
Thrask? He was a good man. That he would be influenced by blood magic is... unfortunate.
It's over. If you continue to chase ghosts, you only give people more reason to think you're mad.
You must let this go.
Many are assumed to be mad... right up until the point they are proven correct.
Still... without proof of Orsino's direct involvement, the grand cleric will never believe as I do.
Thank you, Champion. You have done a fine service for your city.
You will never accept that you're wrong! No wonder so many of your men want you gone.
You're mad!
You're already convinced he's guilty, even if he's not.
You're paranoid.
So Orsino has managed to convince you, as well?
I was hoping you, of all people, might be above the influence of blood magic.
Go. It appears I must deal with this on my own.
Her Grace must realize the threat we face.
You should take care what friends you keep, Champion.
Champion. It seems you are the only one who still responds to my summons.
The mages are responsible, but they have blinded the grand cleric and even those who wear the sun-shield to the truth.
You would think Orsino preaching treason in the market evidence enough, but it seems only you have the sense to see it.
Orsino preaches treason in the market, and yet still more evidence is demanded. It seems beyond reason.
I have seen the evidence—the muddied boots, missing potions. Mages are sneaking out at night for their dark rituals.
Of course. Muddy boots mean blood magic. That's incontrovertible. Good mages wipe their feet first.
The mages are bolder since Orsino spoke out. They are sneaking out of the tower and deceiving my men.
I know how it sounds. Claiming I am irrational has become the latest sport, it seems.
That doesn't sound like very compelling evidence.
There must be more to this.
Yet mages have indeed gone missing only to re-appear later, their absences unreported.
And how, but with blood magic, could they convince my oath-sworn men to lie to my face?
Maybe I can shed some light on this for you.
How can I help?
Thank you, Champion. I knew I could count on you.
I need to bring hard evidence before Grand Cleric Elthina. It is the only way she will believe I am not motivated by hatred.
And what if someone could have prevented what happened to your mother, Champion?
Then I am wrong. I would never ask you to lie, Champion.
One of my loyal men has brought me word of a meeting place the mages travel to at night, a small square in Hightown.
You can go there without arousing suspicion, whereas I cannot.
I appreciate your assistance, Champion.
As if it were too much to ask that the city be kept safe from magic. Orsino is a fool!
She was a good person and didn't deserve her fate.
I'm sorry about Marethari.
I don't need anything from the Dalish.
You can't help me.
I'm always amazed by the beauty of the Dalish.
Your eyes are stunning.
Champion.
Your mage-templar group was conspiring to overthrow Meredith.
I have a sudden deep regret I interfered...
You know, I was half-convinced Meredith had engineered the whole thing, to trick me into incriminating myself.
Thrask admitted to leading the group.
Meredith was not involved.
Perhaps I've exaggerated the depths of her madness. But if she's not there yet, she will be soon.
The only question is, once it's clear she cannot lead, will there be anyone left to oppose her?
If Meredith stays in charge, she'll run Kirkwall into the ground.
She must be overthrown.
Speak softly, friend. There is nowhere safe to say those words.
But be assured, you are not the only one thinking them.
Please accept this as my thanks. It will be of more value to you right now than my friendship.
Do not jump to any conclusions about this group. I only wish to know their purpose.
Meredith has no need of your services here, Champion.
Thank you for coming, Champion. Few will associate with me now that I am the focus of Meredith's ire.
Which leaves me in a difficult position. She is not entirely wrong.
Inform the criers! A miracle has occurred!
I know some of my people are using dangerous means to oppose her, but I cannot seek the templars' aid without making every mage a target.
What are they doing?
Dangerous means?
All I know is numerous mages have left the Circle at night, sometimes for days at a time.
I'd rather not follow our knight-commander by leaping to the worst possible conclusion, but the idea of blood magic has crossed my mind.
She does like to add one and one and get eleven, doesn't she?
Meredith is a bit overzealous.
Sometimes a hundred and eleven.
You need some assistance against traitors in your ranks?
How can I help?
Traitors? Perhaps. Rebels? Certainly.
I don't know if they seek congress with demons, or merely a walk in the moonlight.
Walking's not so bad. Even mages need exercise!
You're underestimating our knight-commander. She'd probably kill the whole city, just to be safe.
Meredith can be overzealous.
She might take on the entire Free Marches.
I have heard rumors, whispers, of a meeting tonight in Hightown.
Fear of the templars doesn't justify going soft on blood mages.
That's no excuse.
I don't know if they're using blood magic or just visiting their families.
All I know is that a meeting is happening tonight in Hightown.
I would go myself, but should I leave the tower without permission, Meredith would call it proof of my involvement.
I'll see what they're up to. There's no point in involving the templars.
Let's resolve this quietly.
Thank you. Your support has been a life-line for me.
So I shouldn't slit my wrists and dance naked under the moonlight just to fit in?
What if she catches me?

I would... not recommend it.
Whatever they're doing, I'll put an end to it.
I'll stop them.
Use discretion. I would rather not deny my mages what small freedoms they can find.

If you are trying to initiate... something, don't bother. I'm not interested in a shemlen.

Very, and I have no interest in antagonizing them. That is partially why I suffer being a messenger today.

You're right, I suppose.
I... thank you.

Varnell

Qunari

I will.

I will.
Of course. But only because you used that you kicked my puppy voice.
I will.

I don't think so.
I'm not sure that's a good idea.
I don't think so.

I don't think so.

And I will repay you, somehow. Dareth shiral.

Whatever comes, you have my support.
Well, perhaps it's time to stop hiding, and I do miss the trouble we used to get into.

Maimed

Burned

Go back

Not quite.
Happy? I would prefer we lived in a world without such sickness, where such madness is unnecessary.
But we do not. Even this battle is not yet over.
Sometimes a limb must be amputated to save a life. Unpleasant, but necessary.
And my surgery here is not yet done.
I have not.
I am beginning to wonder just how large your part in all this actually was.
An apostate come into our city, gathering power and influence? A sudden hero of the people?
A refugee come to our city with an apostate sister, gathering power and influence without any accounting?
How can I trust that the mighty Champion of Kirkwall is not a worse threat to this city than the Circle?
Is helping you destroy the Circle not proof enough?
I supported you.
Proof of what? Your lies? Proof that you are more clever even than Orsino?

You're paranoid.
If you want to see a threat to this city, look in the mirror.

Hmph. Just the sort of misdirection I would expect from you.

I will not allow insubordination! We must stay true to our path!
Andraste's dimpled buttcheeks!
You recognize it, do you not? Pure lyrium, taken from the Deep Roads. The dwarf charged a great deal for his prize.

It won't help you.
The idol poisoned Bartrand's mind in the end.
It killed him, Meredith.
He was weak, whereas I am not!
It seems a lot more sword-like than I remember.
That's the idol?
All of you, I want him dead!
All of you, I want her dead!
No! My brother defended us! Defended you! I won't turn on him now!
No! My sister defended us! Defended you! I won't turn on her now!
No! I won't kill my brother for you!
No! I won't kill my sister for you!
You dare!
Enough, Knight-Commander—I'm ending this. I should have done so long ago.
But I don't need any of you! I will protect this city myself!
You'll have to go through me.
Idiot boy! Just like all the others!
How long has she been like this?
If she plays with that any more, she's going to go blind.
She's lost it. Just like Bartrand.
She's clearly lost her mind!
If you want answers, don't interrupt.
Let her talk.
Take it easy, Varric. She's telling us what she can.
Calm down.
I didn't exactly want to stay for dinner, but I think we've got a few minutes to hear her out.
You in a hurry, Varric?
Blessed are those who stand before the corrupt and the wicked and do not falter!
This is what respect looks like, bas! Some of you will never earn it!
Screams

I will not be defeated!

Screams

How wonderful, more vessels for our experiments.
Perhaps the demons will find one of you suitable.
Is it... Is it over?
Keran?
Yes, that's my name. Oh thank the Maker, I thought He had abandoned me.
But is it only Keran? It could be Keran plus one. A very nasty plus one, at that.
Do not trust him. He is likely possessed.
So, when do we find out if this one's got a demon inside?

Watch yourself. He could still be possessed.

I don't know...
It's... It's clean. There is no scent of demons in his blood.
Well, there's one sure way.
Aaah! What was that about!
If there was a demon in there, it would have defended itself. Looks like he's clear.
What do you remember about how you got here?
What happened to you, Keran?
I... I was with a lady. And then things got fuzzy.
Nightmares, then. On fire for days, a demon laughing. The naked lady with her razor claws... in my chest.
I'd wake and hear screams. Maybe my own?
I'm sorry, it's all a tangle in my head.
You may be possessed.
What? No! I'm not a mage. I can't—
Demons can possess anyone.
I'm just me. You have to believe me!

I do believe you.
No, no. I'm me, I swear.
Go ahead and leave, Keran. You've been through enough.

Don't tell the templars. I-I don't know what they'd do to me.

Cullen needs to hear about this mess.
Be careful when you tell Ser Cullen about this. If it's not handled correctly, innocent mages may suffer for Tarohne's crimes.
We should tell Ser Cullen about this. Maybe earn a templar's favor for a change.
Ser Cullen awaits our word.
I guess it's back to the wretched Gallows. Personally, I could do without blood mages or templars.
I suppose you must report to Ser Cullen.
We have quite the tale to tell Ser Cullen. I wonder if he'll believe us. I wonder if I believe us.
There's fault on both sides. We must find a way to live in peace.
There has to be a better way.
The situation is dealt with. Who is right and wrong is academic.
Whatever. It's done now.
If there is any chance he still harbors a demon in him—
We conducted tests on Keran. He's not possessed. He can stay in the Order.
Keran's fine.
I hesitate to ask what methods you used that you are so certain.
Keran did nothing wrong. You can't strip his livelihood on the off-chance Tarohne succeeded.
Keran should keep his status.
If a demon infiltrated the Templar Order, it would be disastrous.
You can't take any chances.
For your actions, take this. It's the reward I promised and more.
You have done the Order a great service. We will not forget it.
Word of the slaughter spread quickly.
Tell you what. I'll be here if you need me.
You're interested in Merrill, aren't you?

I'm sure my son is quite the symbolic prize.
He is of age. The decision seems rightly his.

I want to let him find his way, but in my position...
He's taken a great deal of inspiration from you. I want to allow his idealism, but not blindly.

At worst... I lose my son.

Does anyone else know?

Bartrand doesn't exactly need the place, now that he's in the sanitarium. I've been trying to sell it.
No point in keeping a house for a dead man. I've been trying to get rid of the place for ages now.
Story time, Hawke! You might want to find a seat for this.
No shit, there I was: I'd found the fortified mansion where my brother was hiding, and all by my lonesome, I broke inside.
The place was in shambles. Corpses in the halls, dead rats the size of Qunari. Every soul dead.
Just tell me what this is about.
Skip to the point, Varric.
I'm getting there. You need to develop a sense of pacing, Hawke.
How did they all die?
What happened?
Well, that's the creepy part.
Are you pulling my leg?
Sounds far-fetched.
Maker's truth! I only found my brother's steward alive, locked in a back room.
He said Bartrand went crazy and killed everyone, including himself.
That bastard deserved to die.
Good.
Can't argue with that. I just wish he'd waited so I could get answers out of him first.
I can't imagine finding something like that. How are you holding up?
I'm sorry.
Don't worry about me. After what Bartrand did, I wasn't exactly planning on giving him a hug and talking things out.
If this is another of your stories and you're just saying this to make me feel terrible, it's working.
Are you serious?
I wish I'd made this up for dramatic effect, but it's the Maker's own truth.
At any rate, now I'm stuck trying to get rid of a mansion that was the site of a few dozen grisly murders.
I'm sure that'll go well.
Good luck.
Yeah, it's been a picnic so far.
I assume there's not much interest in it.
That could be tricky.
No. There's a really small number of people who want expensive, blood-covered houses in Hightown.
I can only imagine there's a huge market for the homes of deranged killers.
Buyers will be thrilled.
The creepy sort of people who are interested are generally not the ones with the coin to take it off my hands.
I found a minor noble in Rivain who bought the place sight unseen. But now there's a problem.
They say the place is... haunted.
Bartrand's atrocities must have weakened the barrier between this world and the Fade.
The Veil was torn.
Maker, I hope not! I don't think I can fix the Veil through applied use of force.
I don't see how that's your problem.
So?
Anyone who knew the house's history would attribute every noise in the night to ghosts.
That's not surprising.
If they hadn't seen the place, I'd expect the first complaint to be about the corpses in the hall.
Is that all?
I may have neglected to mention the mansion's... colorful past to the buyer.
They've noticed some minor problems: Voices whispering in the walls, apparitions, things moving on their own.
My hope is it's a relic Bartrand brought back from the Deep Roads. We smash it, and the haunting stops.
What happens if we do nothing?
And if we don't?
Best case? They drag me before the seneschal and accuse me of fraud.
The worst case involves Antivan Crows.
I'm not an expert on hauntings, but what if smashing something does not make the problem go away?
What if that doesn't fix it?
Ah... that's where things get tricky.
You're a mage! You must know something about... weird shit.
You come from a family with magic, Hawke. You must have experience dealing with... weird.
I'm sure you'll be able to figure something out that will help.
Can't you do this yourself?
Why do you need me?
Hawke, I'm a businessman. Now and then, I shoot people. I don't know anything about ghosts or magic.
It's entirely possible that even if I find the thing that's causing the trouble, I won't be able to stop it on my own.
Very well. We'll investigate the mansion. Again.
We'll take care of it.
Thanks, Hawke. I knew you wouldn't let me down.
I've got a lot to do right now, Varric. You'll have to sort this out on your own this time.
We don't have time.
I didn't think you'd let me down, Hawke. First time for everything.
Fine, we'll take care of it.
We'll take care of it.
Thanks, Hawke. I appreciate it.
You can handle this on your own just like last time.
We don't have time.
Right, there's a shocker.
This should be fun.
Don't be so nervous.
You're only the second human I've seen up close. Last time was not a happy memory.
I've never met a human before. Dalish mothers frighten their children with stories about you, you know.
Where there's one demon, there's usually more. Where do we start digging?
Let's hunt some demons.
He also disappeared.
I fear it is time to widen this investigation. My discretion may have cost me one of our best recruits, Wilmod's friend Keran.
They were last seen together at the Blooming Rose.
But I had no luck interrogating the, ah, young ladies there. I doubt they know anything of magic or demons.
I'll speak with them. You never know how much you can learn from pillow talk.
Maybe I'll have better luck.
I'd be willing to search there.
The brothel, huh?
Don't be fooled by a pretty face.
I don't trust them.
They fear we would shut them down if they admit to serving our recruits. Perhaps you could talk to them?
A Grey Warden took away one of our hunters to fight the darkspawn.
I heard he fought the Archdemon. I wonder what's become of him.
I heard she fought the Archdemon. I wonder what's become of her.
Not you, personally, of course. I'm sure they don't have any tales about you. Or not scary ones, at least.
Not that you're not notable enough to have a story... I'll just shut up now.
The Keeper said you came from Ferelden. I spent most of my life there. We only came north a few years ago.
The Order would truly be in your debt if you helped us with this.
No one at the brothel will speak with me for fear I would shut them down for serving our recruits.
It is the only lead we have on Keran.
Our recruits may be in grave danger, to their bodies and souls.
If you learn what manner of creature did this to Wilmod, please come tell me in the Gallows. I will ensure you are rewarded.
You killed them all by yourself!
This is far off the beaten path. What brought you here?
How did you end up here?
Ships have been going missing. A local told me raiders were lighting bonfires here on foggy days.
They were tricking ships into running ashore, thinking they'd reached Kirkwall. Then they'd plunder them.
When we arrived, we found Evets Marauders. If it weren't for you...
I'm glad our paths crossed. Otherwise this might have had a very different ending.
Happy to help.
Marauders slain, guardsmen rescued. It's what I do.
I do good work.
If that's it, I have other things to do.
We done here?
There's a massive bounty offered on the Marauders. Help us kill them, and you'll be rich.
Blast!
Have you been in the Free Marches long? Do you like it here?
The Blight forced me here. Wasn't my choice.
I had to come here.
I've lived in Kirkwall for a year now. It's a good place to get a fresh start.
There's opportunity.
I miss the cold. And the dirt. Kirkwall's not brown enough for me. But hey, no darkspawn!
Could be worse.
Will you kill me for this?
Take Flemeth's amulet to the altar at the top of Sundermount.
Return the amulet to Keeper Marethari in the Dalish camp.
Merrill has arrived safely in the alienage.
I— Anders, what did you do?
It's like... you brought a piece of the Fade into this world.
I had already forgotten what that feels like.
I thought the Tranquil were cut off from the Fade forever.
But you're Tranquil.
When you're Tranquil, you never think on your life before.
But... it's like the Fade itself is inside Anders. Burning like a sun.
What did you do? Not the Fade part—the angry glowing bit.
That's a good question.
It's like a gateway to the Fade inside you. Glowing like a beacon.
I have... some unique circumstances, yes. But, Karl, what happened? How did they get you?
The templars here are far more vigilant than in Ferelden. They found a letter I was writing you...
This bastard ratted you out to the templars.
He tricked you, Anders.
He wasn't himself. Being made Tranquil takes away everything human inside you.
He wasn't capable of caring for me anymore. He could only follow the rules.
You cannot imagine it, Anders. All the color, all the music in the world, gone.
I would gladly give up my magic, but this? I'll never be whole again.
Please, kill me before I forget again! I don't know how you brought it back, but it's fading.
Maybe we can find a cure.
Is there no other way?
I would rather die than be Tranquil. Help him.
Do as he asks.
The Tranquil I've met seem content with their lot. Maybe it's not that bad.
Don't kill him.
Karl, no—
My sister calls being Tranquil a fate worse than death. Give him peace.
Do as he asks.
I understand. We wouldn't have come here by choice either.
Really? I hope you're right.
Ferelden wasn't that brown! The dirt and muck gave it character.
Make Varric a rival
Make Varric a rival
Bartrand Spared
Bartrand Spared
Bartrand Killed
Bartrand Killed
It's a funeral, of sorts. I'll perform it when we get to the mountaintop.
Getting there is the tricky part. Our hunters haven't been able to reach the summit. Dark things are about.
No, not personally. My people tell stories of her, though.
The Keeper brought us here to wait for you. I don't know much more than that.
Of course. Best if we hurry, though. I'd like to be away from here.
You're very lucky. Most people who meet Asha'bellanar wind up in little pieces... hanging from the trees.
I do know that you have Asha'bellanar's amulet, and we must bring it to the altar on the mountaintop. Nothing more.
Can you cure a beheading? The dreams of Tranquil mages are severed—there is nothing left of them to fix.
I would rather die a mage than live as a templar puppet.
I got here too late. I'm sorry, Karl. I'm so sorry.
You have no idea. Your emotions, your dreams, everything—stripped away on someone's whim!
If I were made Tranquil, I would wish for a friend compassionate enough to kill me.
Karl, I'm sorry—
Now! It's fading... Why do you look at me like that?
Goodbye.
We should leave before more templars come.
If you go to Kirkwall, you'll be an apostate in a city full of templars.
Yet you risk the city's danger.
I know, but if I don't go to Kirkwall, I'll be alone. A solitary elf is easy prey for anyone.
In the city, I can get lost in the crowd.

You have been a good friend, better than I deserve.

Do you think we could stop by my house in the alienage? There's something I ought to show you.

That's unexpected.
There's no way you're talking about the same Bartrand that I met.
You're making this up.

I'm worried about you. You're enjoying this a little too much.
You seem a little eager.
I am, aren't I? Giggles
Whatever you do, just make sure he takes me to Castillon. I'll leave a trail for you to follow.
Ordinarily, I'd have taunted Bartrand into an insensible rage. That day, though, I couldn't do it.
I don't think it was a dish to Bartrand.
Maker's truth! There were tears in his eyes! I never thought that was possible before.
Come on, haven't you ever wanted to slap me? Just a little?
Er... now you're making me nervous.
Get back here, you—! Grunts Skittish bitch.
Present for— What?
I'm the Champion of Kirkwall. I have to think about my reputation.
I can't be seen with you.
Are you insane?
Shut up.
That's enough from you.
How dare you?
I just want you out of the way.
You're too much trouble.
The lights! Mother, the lights!
How would you feel if I told you there might be a demon living in you? Just a small one.
Don't make any sudden moves, Keran. You could have a demon in you.
There's no easy way to say this, Keran. There's a chance you're inhabited by a demon.
If there's even the slightest chance you're possessed, the templars need to know.
I have to tell the templars.
The knight-commander needs vigilance and obedience in these trying times.
It is a great honor to serve the Order and the knight-commander.
I'm certain that Keran was discharged for good reason.
Keran is back. The knight-captain said that there will be no more recruits kidnapped.
The mages have spies in our order, I tell you. You can't trust anyone.
I hear the Qunari are kidnapping mages and doing peculiar things to them. Mark my words.
Keran was cast out of the order. No one will tell us why.
Keran's back. But the others? No one will say.
Always the demon thing. Can't you people say no?
Careful, Hawke. She may be an abomination.
How could you let a demon trick you into this? Were you taught nothing?
She must be an abomination. I think.
These mages always fall to the first demon's promise.
This demon-worship thing is a real turn-off.
She has given in to a demon's demands. It is in control now.
Most abominations aren't quite so open about being slaves to demons.
I am not some hopeless waif that ran crying to a demon—I sought them out and embraced them!
That's the wench we're looking for. Gut her!
I wouldn't advise talking with me, serah.
I dared question one of the knight-commander's orders.
Now I am a pariah. All for saying what a great many of us are feeling.
I fear the Templar Order here has lost its way.
I've been loyal to the Order. But the knight-commander doesn't make it easy.
Effective immediately, Keran, you are discharged from the Templar Order. Escort him from the grounds.
What? I was tortured. I've done nothing wrong!
Set a guard to watch him. Just in case.

This is Martin's cargo? It's... it's all poison. Illegal poison.
I wouldn't breathe that in, if I were you. Looks like Martin's trading in death.
I... I think that's venom. So much for going on the straight and narrow.
Poison. This has to be illegal. I knew we shouldn't have trusted that snake.
I believe that poison you hold is illegal, even in Tevinter. Martin has a lot to answer for.
Ooh. The Black Hand! A blend of twenty-seven toxic plant essences with a healthy dollop of cobra venom for that extra kick!
Why would anyone need so much poison? Is he planning to murder all of Kirkwall?
This is some potent stuff. You could wipe out all of Hightown with just one vial.
And I have a room at the Hanged Man, if you're looking for... company later.
Martin was transporting illegal poisons. I'll need an explanation for this.
That poison will kill a man in two breaths. Can I have it?
A true disaster. There is no pleasing anyone after this.
I wonder if actually warring with the Qunari would cause as much damage as this disaster?
The viscount appreciates your assistance. Now leave me.
The viscount will see no one. He has... cleared his schedule.
I would prefer that you were not involved at all, but that is neither here nor there.
It sounds like you don't want them found.
You seem reluctant to look.
I'm sure you have suspicions about what happened.
So what is known?
I don't need your opinion. Get to what you know.
Just get to the facts.
I am to help you, yes. Viscount Dumar would appreciate discretion in this matter.
I must think of what is best for the viscount's office. Bringing attention to such an incident benefits no one.
You would do nothing?
The Qunari are neutral hostiles at best. There is no relationship to salvage by... overextending ourselves on their behalf.
Why can't you surprise me in a normal way? With flowers, maybe, or a cake?
This is unexpected.
The delegate and his entourage could not be made to disappear without the knowledge of the city guard.
Have any failed to report?
Several. You should start with one of them.
Not coincidentally, a number of recent recruits have failed to report. You should start with one of them.
Although, where you find a swordsman so eager to sell his honor and duty, I'm sure I don't know.
The Hanged Man.
Hanged Man.
No doubt.
Obvious one, that.
Definitely.
Got to be.
Hanged Man.
Hanged Man.
Hanged Man.
Hanged Man.
No question.
Right. Then you know what to look for.
The Hanged Man.
The Hanged Man.
The Hanged Man.
The Hanged Man.
The Hanged Man.
The Hanged Man. Got to be.
Debug Fence
So, where would you start? If you were the starting type.
Do you have anything useful?
My concerns are well founded. This could not have escaped the notice of the city guard. Unless they were involved.
I would begin with the most obvious failure. It's clear the city guard has no excuse for allowing this. Unless they were involved.
I can't imagine this has occurred without notice. There is always a weak link.
Please keep this quiet. The viscount is under enough scrutiny as it is.
If you think investigating the Hanged Man will yield information on the missing Qunari, I suggest you get to it.
I am getting rid of him. Through peaceful means.
Coming from her, that's priceless.
I saw the ship docked in the harbor, Castillon. She is splendid. I want her.
What could go wrong? I'm sure everything will be fine!
Oh! Tell me you've decided to help retrieve my property after all! I'm desperate! I'm begging you!
Are you Anso?
Aaah!
Sweet mother of partha! You can't just run up on someone like that!
Are you... the human Athenril told me about? The one looking for work?
Are you... the one that mercenary told me about? The one looking for work?
I used to work with Athenril, if that's what you mean.
That's me.
I used to work with the Red Iron, if that's what you mean.
That's me.
Yes it is! What I mean, that is.
Did you think I was going to attack you?
Expecting someone else?
Oh! No, no! Or I hope not, anyhow!
Just tell me what you want.
Depends on the work.
Of course! Listen to me, babbling like a lyrium smuggler! Which I'm not.
My apologies, human. I haven't been on the surface very long. I keep thinking I'll fall up into that sky any minute!
Bartrand used to be like that. Got jumpy every time he stepped outside.
What a bizarre thing to be scared of.
I'd pay to see that.
Dwarves are funny.
But I digress! I need some help. Rather badly, in fact. Some product of mine has been... misplaced.
The men who were supposed to deliver it decided not to. If you retrieve my property, I could reward you handsomely...?
Just what did these men steal?
What kind of property?
Did I say steal? I don't know if I would go that far.
They seemed like perfectly reasonable smugglers. They smiled and everything!
The goods are valuable, however. And illegal. And my client wants them very, very badly! You know how these templars can be.
You're smuggling lyrium to the templars?
So it's lyrium?
Brave man.
Shh! By the Paragons, not so loudly!
My word! I'm not cut out for this. I should have taken that job sweeping stables like Mother insisted.
I'll get it back for you.
I'll do it.
Oh, thank goodness!
I don't run errands.
Forget it.
Nug droppings! Does nobody in this city wish to make coin? Now what will I do?
Sighs If you change your mind, please tell me. I'm desperate!
Make it worth my time, and I'll help you.
This better be worth it.
Oh, I will! Or I'll try to.
The gentlemen conduct their business at night in a little hovel within the alienage.
If you have to kill them, then I guess it can't be avoided. But I'm sure they'll be reasonable!
Wait!
Mind your manners. This is my territory.
Wounded Coast
Slaver Caverns
This is strange. I've never seen the alienage this quiet, even at night.
The alienage should not be this quiet.
It's a little quiet here tonight. Too quiet.
All the elves have run off to hide in their homes? That can't be good.
Seems a bit quiet in the alienage tonight, doesn't it?
Huh. It's so quiet you could hear a mouse fart.
When it's this quiet, that's when they attack. I'm just saying.
Seems a little too quiet tonight.
I've got some good news and some bad news...
What? What is it?
Good news, Keran is safe. Bad news, half of your recruits may have been possessed by demons.
Blood mages have infiltrated your ranks. They've been implanting your recruits with demons.
Sweet blood of Andraste!
D-Demons? Did you say something about the recruits and demons?
I didn't want to tell you, Macha. They... they were horrible. Those mages see the rest of us as ants to be crushed.
They won't stop until they've destroyed the Chantry and the templars forever.
Tarohne was crazy. Magic didn't make her that way.
Not all mages are like that.
Not all mages are like that.
Hey! I'm a mage!
True, not every mage gives in to temptation, but none are ever free of it.
Mages have been systematically abused by the templars for a thousand years.
It's the templars' fault.
How can you say that after what you've seen?
Wrong! This is no stuffy scholars' debate. This is the central fact of the world that Andraste recognized.
At any time, any mage could become a monster, from the lowest apprentice to the most seasoned enchanters.
Mages cannot be treated like people. They are not like you and me.
Surely that's a little harsh.
They are weapons. They have the power to light a city on fire in a fit of pique.
I admit, that does reduce their bargaining position. But there must be some middle ground.
There has to be a better way.
It does no good driving mages to blood magic as their only escape.
There has to be a better way.
Perhaps you're right. Perhaps mages need better education as to why the Chantry functions as it does.
Perhaps they would not go against the will of Andraste herself. I will look into it.
For now, Keran, unless it is proven you are free of demons, I must strip you of your commission immediately.
The templars have good reason to be vigilant.
You're right.
Keran, I'm afraid I must relieve you of your commission.
No! You can't really think that! Keran's fine. He's safe.
Please, ser. I tried to resist. I never took anything they offered.
I-I need this position or my sister can't eat. I've been training for five years!
Still, you have done much for us by stopping these blood mages. I will heed your request.
Please, Knight-Captain. I'll prove I'm loyal. Ask me anything.
My brother's a good man, ser. He would never succumb to a demon.
Perhaps it is best to keep our enemies close. We can watch him far better here than in the city. So be it.
If he has shown no sign of demonic possession in ten years' time, Keran will become eligible for full knighthood.
Thank you, serah. Again. But without a full knighthood, Keran's pay is so small... I do not know if I can reward you as you deserve—
I will handle that, miss.
No! Why bother to save me if you're just going to cast me into the streets?
My brother is a good man, serah! You cannot truly think this of him!
They were clearly expecting someone.
Someone must have tipped them off.
Were they expecting us? It seemed that way.
Surprise, surprise. It seemed too easy.
I guess they're not going to give anything back now, huh?
So much for them being reasonable. Let's find the stash and go.
Well that was unhealthy. Shall we find our smuggled goods now?
Anso's goods are probably in that chest.
It's empty.
Waste of bloody time! Who put us up to this?
Aww. An empty chest is like an empty bed. What a waste.
Well, so much for that.
So what now?
Whatever that dwarf wanted is long gone.
I don't think anyone came out unscathed. What now?
Nobody came out of that looking good. What now?
I doubt any side was satisfied. And now?
A mess for everyone. What now?
About that... Hawke, there's something I need to tell you. At your house. Very, very soon.
Go to the Hanged Man at night to look for the guards who allowed the Qunari to be taken.
Why do you even care?
Is there a reason you're interested?
Now we're family?
Remember the time you ran off with the relic?
Quite easily.
Castillon deserved what he got, didn't he?
I really hate it when you're right.
You know I'm right.
Stop whining.
Sighs You are.
That's not what I meant!
You're not filling me with confidence, Isabela.
There's always something to look forward to.
Do I even want to know, Isabela? No, don't answer.
Why do you even care?
Is there a reason why you're interested?
Now you want to start asking questions?
Hawke. I have something to tell you. At your house. Very, very soon.
She's close. Fastest thing on the ocean, or so I've been told.
It was my decision.
The Arishok is the one to worry about. We wait for his reaction.
Not our move. We wait to see what the Arishok does.
The rest isn't up to us. Not yet. We get back to business and wait to see what the Arishok does.
The Arishok's the one to worry about. So we clean up and wait for trouble to find us.
Back to business while the Arishok decides how to respond, I guess.
Well, that was a mess. Better get things in order before the Arishok responds.
Better than three greased-up sailors.
Can't be good. The viscount's son, Qunari in the chantry. Bet it's going to rain, too.
When was the last time I ate? Who's cooking tonight? Sandal? Maker. Enchantment soup again.
Thumb right in the bowl last time. His enchanting hand, too. Yeah, I saw you, you squirrelly little knot-head.
Did I lock my chambers? I bet he's in there now. Ugh.
That guy looking at me? A lot of illness in this city. What's he looking at? Loony.
Yeah, that's it, keep walking. Can't trust anyone. Could be lyrium addled, Fade-crazed.
Hard enough doing this without soaking my hides. Thirty pounds of water and it's a march with no rations.

Dear Hawke,
Here is your share of the Bone Pit payment. Please spend it at my store.
Love, Hubert

To my new partner,
I'm pleased that you joined the Bone Pit Mining Venture! Unfortunately, in light of the recent dragon infestation, the mine is not quite profitable at the moment. In the near future, you may expect to receive significant profits in exchange for your active participation in our business.
As our verbal agreement was not quite binding by Kirkwall law, I'm sending you this small sum as your first investment dividend. You realize that by accepting this, you are now legally bound to the Bone Pit Mining Venture.
Sincerely, Hubert

Hawke,
Convincing the miners to return has allowed the Bone Pit Mining Venture to resume operation much sooner than if I'd had to hire all new workers.
As our business has returned to marginal profitability, I've enclosed your next dividend! I do hope you'll spend this sum wisely and not waste it on that ill-advised expedition to the Deep Roads I've been hearing about.
There is plenty of profit to be made in Kirkwall without having to risk life and limb! Should you happen to become blighted in the Deep Roads, I'm afraid that will void our partnership agreement.
Sincerely, Hubert

Hawke,
Your next dividend from the Bone Pit Mining Venture, which I've enclosed, is smaller than I had hoped.
Soon after the mine began to turn a profit, those Coterie jackals moved in to claim what is rightfully ours. They've warned me not to refuse their generous offer of protection. I had little choice but to submit to their extortion.
Someday I hope the Coterie will get their due. But for now, they are simply too powerful to refuse.
Hubert

Hawke,
I've enclosed your latest dividend. It is smaller than usual due to attacks on our shipments over the last year.
Since you've been so busy lately, I've had to take leave of my shop in Hightown in order to track down who is responsible for these thefts. Our Coterie protection has been useless, and I won't be surprised if they're involved.
Hubert

Hawke,
Here's your latest dividend. I believe you'll find it quite satisfactory.
Profits have been soaring since you ended the bastard who was ambushing our shipments. The Coterie was actually apologetic for once! Thanks to one of their own being responsible for the thefts, they've agreed to waive their fee for the next two years.
Now if only we could get the workers to stop winging about the harsh conditions. They actually expect me to hire guards for them. Well… that's what I have you for, partner!
At your earliest convenience, please visit the Bone Pit to see whatever the miners are concerned with now. That Jansen fellow seems to be the loudest source of discontent.
Hubert

Hawke,
Here is your next dividend. As you can see, profits are increasing!
Unfortunately, grievances are also increasing. Resolving their last dilemma has made our workers feel entitled! Honestly, I don't see why they couldn't have squashed the spiders themselves. They do have pickaxes!
In any case, please make another trip to the Bone Pit when you get a chance.
Hubert

Hawke,
I imagine that was nasty business with those undead. You've earned this dividend, partner. I can't imagine how the mines became infested.
The flapping tongues of our workers carried the news into town, and several Kirkwallers have begun chiding me about the Bone Pit being cursed and other such nonsense. And now some city official has threatened a citation if I don't hire guards for the mines within the next year.
To top it all off, those miners are whining more boldly than ever! Now they expect brand new equipment. Perhaps you can set them straight the next time you visit the Bone Pit.
Hubert

Hawke,
This dividend is small, due to your limited involvement in the development of the Bone Pit Mining Venture. I've had to handle most business matters that I depend on you for myself. It leads me to rethinking our partnership arrangement.
In the future, I hope you will take your business responsibilities more seriously.
Hubert

Champion,
Here's your latest dividend. It's a bit reduced this time. I had to pay the annual bonuses to the guards we hired last year. I suppose they are earning their pay, since their presence greatly decreases the complaints I receive, not to mention incidents of monsters mangling our miners.
This may seems sudden, but I'm thinking of retiring from the mining business. These past several years have been very profitable, but I feel a need to refocus on buying and selling high-end fine goods.
I'd like you to consider buying out my share of the Bone Pit Mining Venture. Think on it, and we'll speak when I return from my business outside of Kirkwall.
Hubert

The Deep Roads.
